title: 103_s1078
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Jena Band of Choctaw Indians of Louisiana Confirmation Act". The findings are also included in the Act. The Congress finds that the Jena Band of Choctaw ancestors were identified as "Fullblood Mississippi Choctaw Indians" in 1903 and 1904. Over 60% of the Jena Band of Choctaw members can prove one-half or more Choctaw Indian blood quantum. High blood degree is not a requirement for maintaining a Federal tribal relationship. The Jena Band of Choctaw has maintained a distinct dialect of the Choctaw language since historic times, demonstrating a separate and distinct historic band of Choctaw. Their Choctaw ancestors resided in close proximity in historic Catahoula Parish, as shown in Federal population censuses from 1880 to 1910. The Jena Band of Choctaw has a long history in the La Salle, Grant, and Rapides Parishes, with 72 percent of the current members still residing in the area. They can trace their traditional and elected leaders from 1850 to the present, showing continuity in political influence. The Tribe's Federal relationship is confirmed by other federally recognized tribes in Louisiana and the Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Tribe" refers to the Jena Band of Choctaw Indians of Louisiana. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Interim Council" refers to the Board of Directors of the Jena Band of Choctaw Indians of Louisiana. The term "member" refers to an individual enrolled on the membership roll of the Tribe. The term "State" refers to the State of Louisiana.

SEC. 4. CONFIRMATION OF FEDERAL RELATIONSHIP. Federal Recognition as a Tribe is confirmed for the Jena Band of Choctaw Indians of Louisiana. Federal laws applicable to Indians and Indian tribes, including the Indian Reorganization Act, shall apply to the Tribe and its members. SEC. 5. RECOGNITION OF RIGHTS. This Act does not diminish any existing rights or privileges of the Tribe or its members. It does not alter any rights or obligations related to property, contracts, hunting, fishing, trapping, gathering, water rights, or tax obligations before the enactment of this Act. SEC. 6. FEDERAL SERVICES AND BENEFITS. The Tribe and its members are eligible for all Federal services and benefits available to federally recognized Indian tribes. Members of the Jena Band of Choctaw Indians residing in specific Louisiana parishes are considered to be residing on a reservation for service availability. The Tribe is recognized as an Indian tribe for tax purposes under the Indian Tribal Government Tax Status Act. SEC. 7. ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT. The Secretary will negotiate with the Tribe to establish an economic development plan within 2 years of adopting a tribal constitution. Any property transfer in the plan must comply with section 11. SEC. 8. INTERIM GOVERNMENT. Until a tribal constitution is adopted, the Tribe will be governed by the Interim Council. SEC. 9. MEMBERSHIP. The Jena Band of Choctaw membership list from December 1, 1984, serves as the base roll for the Tribe, pending Secretary approval. Eligibility criteria include having at least one-fourth Choctaw Indian blood from Catahoula Parish ancestors and not being a member of another federally recognized tribe. After adoption of a tribal constitution, membership in the Jena Band of Choctaw Tribe is governed by specific requirements outlined in the Articles of Incorporation. Individuals must meet criteria such as being a lineal descendant of a listed individual or having Choctaw ancestry from Catahoula Parish. Additionally, they cannot be a member of another federally recognized Indian tribe. The Jena Band of Choctaw Tribe's membership is governed by specific requirements outlined in the Articles of Incorporation, including being a lineal descendant or having Choctaw ancestry from Catahoula Parish, and not being a member of another federally recognized Indian tribe. The Interim Council can request the Secretary to conduct a secret ballot election to adopt a tribal constitution within 1 year of this Act. Absentee voting is allowed, and the election must follow specific procedures. After adopting a constitution, an election for tribal officials must be held within 120 days, following the constitution's procedures. The governing body of the Tribe established under the constitution adopted shall be treated as an Indian tribal government for purposes of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and all other Federal laws applicable to Indians and Indian tribes. SEC. 11. REAL PROPERTY. Any real property taken in trust by the Secretary shall be subject to existing rights and obligations, including liens, mortgages, and taxes. The property held in trust shall be exempt from Federal, State, and local taxation. The Senate passed the legislation on August 5, 1993. Walter J. Stewart attested to the document as Secretary.
